questions.question: How do you …………………………. the vacuum cleaner?

questions.question: I was annoyed ………………………… the way she conducted herself.
I was surprised …………………………. his attitude

questions.question: What are you wearing ………………………… your sweater?

questions.question: I earn …………………………. money than a sweeper.

questions.question: I ……………………………… to ride a bicycle.

questions.question: Every country has ………………………………. traditions.
questions.description: It's means it is or it has.

questions.question: An enormous frog sat ………………………………. the grass.

questions.question: Seldom ……………………………….. seen such a dangerous animal.

questions.question: Little …………………………………. realize the danger she faced.

questions.question: ……………………………… I have taken to making my own clothes.

questions.question: .................................. he said made no sense to me.

questions.question: ………………… child can learn to sing.

questions.question: The cow provides milk ………………………… is a nutritious food.

questions.question: His uncle ………………………. was a millionaire sent him to England for higher studies.

questions.question: …………………………. three suspects have been arrested.

questions.question: We spend ………………………… weekends at our country cottage.

questions.question: Why are you staring ………………………. like that?
questions.description: Some verbs need a preposition before their object.

questions.question: ……………………….. I am going to jump over the stream.
questions.description: The preposition is dropped when there is no object.

questions.question: We arrived ……………………………… the station in the morning.
questions.description: A preposition is usually used before an expression of place.

questions.question: We seem …………………………….. a problem.
………………………….. the existence of antidrug laws, drug dealers persist in selling drugs illegally.
questions.description: We need a preposition before a noun. Although is used before a clause.

questions.question: ………………………… we have anti-drug laws, drug dealers continue to sell narcotics illegally.
questions.description: We use although to introduce a clause.

questions.question: The writer ………………………. that global warming is a major threat to the planet.
questions.description: We use the simple present to talk about opinions.

questions.question: ………………………… my childhood was peaceful, my adulthood is very hectic and stressful.
questions.description: We use while to connect two contrasting ideas.

questions.question: ……………………….. I get sunburn quite easily, I don’t sunbathe.
questions.description: Since can introduce the reason or cause.

questions.question: ………………………….. I studied at university I sold burgers.
questions.description: We can use while to talk about two situations that happen at the same time.

questions.question: The schools cancelled the classes after the thunderstorm ………………………….. students could be safe.
questions.description: We use so that to express intention or purpose.

questions.question: ……………………………. his long legs, he is a good basketball player.
questions.description: All of these can be used to indicate the reason.

questions.question: Companies don’t want to invest in countries where taxes are high. ………………………… increasing taxes will affect the economy.
questions.description: Therefore is a transitional adverb. It does not connect two clauses. So is a conjunction. It connects two clauses.

questions.question: Companies don’t want to invest in countries where taxes are high ………………………… increasing taxes will affect the economy.
questions.description: So is a coordinating conjunction that connects two clauses of equal rank.

questions.question: ………………………. companies don’t want to invest in countries where taxes are high, increasing taxes will affect the economy.
questions.description: Both since and because can give the reason for something.

questions.question: I enjoy reading books ………………………. motivate me.
questions.description: The relative pronoun that can refer to both people and things.

questions.question: Susie ……………………….. a new boyfriend.
questions.description: Either could be used here. However, the got form of have is more common.

questions.question: I ……………………….. fever last week.
questions.description: Got forms are not common with had.

questions.question: …………………………… good neighbors when you lived in the city?
questions.description: Got forms are not common with had.

questions.question: I ………………………….. a toothache.
questions.description: Progressive forms of have are not normally used with meanings that refer to a state.

questions.question: You ………………………….. to work on Sundays.
questions.description: In negative sentences we use do not have.

questions.question: Suddenly I ………………………. a thud.
questions.description: We use listen to to talk about paying attention to sounds that are going on.

questions.question: Can you help me ……………………….. my ring?
questions.description: The infinitive can be used with or without to after help.

questions.question: How ………………………. is she?
questions.description: We use tall for people, trees, buildings etc.

questions.question: You have got lovely ………………………… legs.
questions.description: Parts of the body can be long, not tall.

questions.question: How …………………………. Sundays!
questions.description: The verb comes after the subject in exclamations.

questions.question: How ……………………….. grown!
questions.description: The verb comes after the subject in exclamations.

questions.question: Stir well ………………………. I do.
questions.description: In comparisons we use as, like or the way. We don’t use how.

questions.question: She ……………………….. red and ran out of the room.
questions.description: Turn is common before color words. It is used to talk about visible changes of state.

questions.question: Alice is the person ………………………… keeps a deer in the garden shed.
questions.description: We use who to refer to people.

questions.question: A deer is …………………………. Alice keeps in the garden shed.
The baby’s eyes are not at all the same color ………………………… yours.
questions.description: We can use the structure same …as to say that people or things are similar.

questions.question: She looks ……………………. older than her daughter.
questions.description: We can use no to modify a comparative word.

questions.question: I haven’t seen him ………………………… ages.
questions.description: We use for to indicate duration.

questions.question: Samuel and ………………………. decided to split up.
questions.description: Contractions are not normally written with double subjects.

questions.question: The village ……………………….. I live is very beautiful.
questions.description: Where can mean that…in.

questions.question: If you have already had measles, you are unlikely to get …………………………… again.
questions.description: The names of illnesses are usually uncountable in English and hence we use singular pronouns to refer back to them.

questions.question: I have difficulty …………………………… dates.
questions.description: The preposition ‘in’ can be dropped out after difficulty.

questions.question: My grandfather is eighty-five but he still enjoys ……………………….. health.
questions.description: Health is an uncountable noun. We cannot use an article with it.

questions.question: Have you bought the …………………………?
questions.description: Although groceries is an uncountable noun, it has no singular form.

questions.question: The eruption of the volcano is an ……………………… sight.
questions.description: Awesome means majestic or inspiring.

questions.question: It was an ……………………… movie. I shouldn’t have watched it.
questions.description: Awful means bad, dreadful or terrible.

questions.question: He never took a ………………………. glance.
questions.description: Backward can be an adjective and an adverb. Backwards is an adverb.

questions.question: Bacteria ………………………. in the air we breathe and the food we eat.
questions.description: Bacteria is a plural noun and should take a plural verb.

questions.question: I feel …………………….. enough to go to the hospital.
questions.description: When a person feels ill, he feels bad.

questions.question: Don’t feel ………………………… about losing the match.
questions.description: When you feel sorry about something, you feel bad about it.

questions.question: The student was admonished for behaving ………………………. in the class.
questions.description: Badly means improperly. It is an adverb and modifies the verb behaving.

questions.question: She wants a new job …………………………
questions.description: Badly can mean very much.

questions.question: Customs officers examined all ………………………. at the airport.
questions.description: Baggage is an uncountable noun. It does not have a plural form.

questions.question: We watched the fight with ………………………. breath.
questions.description: Bait is a lure. Bated means held in.

questions.question: When the rescuers found the castaway, he ………………………… alive.
questions.description: Barely means almost not. It has a negative force and hence you cannot use another negative word with it.

questions.question: She was so weak that she ....................................... hardly walk.
questions.description: Hardly has a negative meaning.

questions.question: A grandparent’s job is easier than ………………………….
questions.description: When we make comparisons both nouns should be in the same case. Since the first noun is in the possessive case here, the second noun too should be in the possessive case. We can make a possessive form by adding apostrophe s or with the structure that/those of.

questions.question: Take your coat and pass me …………………………...
questions.description: We cannot use one immediately after my.

questions.question: Do you think Trollope’s novels are more entertaining than ……………………………..?
questions.description: ‘Those of Dickens’ itself is a possessive term.

questions.question: …………………………. you have passed your test, I will give you a job.
questions.description: Once can mean after or as soon as

questions.question: We can go for a walk ……………………………. the rain has stopped.
questions.description: We cannot use that after once.

questions.question: Not only …………………………. clothing, but they are also short of medicine.
questions.description: When not only comes at the beginning, it is followed by an inverted word order. That means the auxiliary goes before the subject.

questions.question: I haven’t bought you ……………………….
questions.description: We do not normally use something in negative clauses.

questions.question: ………………………….., he failed the test.
questions.description: We use not to make a clause negative.

questions.question: Call me when you arrive ……………………………. late it is.
questions.description: No matter how means the same as however.

questions.question: …………………………… you say, I won’t believe you.
questions.description: No matter what means the same as whatever.

questions.question: I …………………………….. support the congress party.
questions.description: We do not use no more to mean that an action or situation has stopped.

questions.question: …………………………. helped me when I was in trouble.
questions.description: No one means not any one.

questions.question: Everybody was there …………………………… Samuel.
questions.description: But can mean except after all, every, none, any or no.

questions.question: ………………………….. the storm, we would have been home before evening.
questions.description: But for can mean if something had not existed or happened. Except for is not used with this meaning.

questions.question: Nobody but …………………………… would act so foolishly.
questions.description: We normally use object pronouns after but subject pronouns are possible in a more formal style.

questions.question: We got it out ………………………….. a screwdriver.
questions.description: We use with when we talk about the tool or object we use to get a result.

questions.question: It takes me only about 5 minutes to …………………………. ready.
questions.description: We do not use become to talk about deliberate actions.

questions.question: I couldn’t help …………………………. what they said.
questions.description: We use an ing form after cannot help / could not help.

questions.question: I can’t help but ………………………………. where she has disappeared.
questions.description: After can’t help but we use an infinitive without to.

questions.question: They got married in January, and got divorced six months …………………………
questions.description: Later means at a time in the future or after the time you have mentioned.

questions.question: I will make all your dreams ………………………………… true.
questions.description: The infinitive is used without to after make.

questions.question: Everything came …………………………… in the end.
questions.description: Come is used in some fixed expressions. Common examples are come true and come right.

questions.question: When did you ………………………….. to live in this town?
questions.description: We use come to talk about movements to the place where the speaker or the hearer is.

questions.question: I want to ……………………….. and live somewhere else.
questions.description: We use go for movements to other places.

questions.question: The Minister has …………………… to come.
questions.description: Before an infinitive, we use agree, not accept.

questions.question: In most countries you have to be …………………….. 18 to drive a car.
questions.description: We use over to talk about ages and speeds.

questions.question: The boys swam ……………………….. the river.
questions.description: We usually prefer across to talk about movement in water.

questions.question: ……………………….. scientists, smoking can cause cancer.
questions.description: According to scientists means ‘if what scientists say is true’.

questions.question: The boy jumped ……………………….. the wall.
questions.description: Over can mean on or to the other side of something high.

questions.question: I am interested ……………………….. to fly.
questions.description: The adjective ‘interested’ is usually followed by ‘in + noun/ ing form’.

questions.question: I am anxious for my daughter ……………………….. a good job.
questions.description: Anxious to get means eager to get.

questions.question: My ………………………. jobs were very stressful.
questions.description: The adjectives first, second, next and last usually go before one, two, three etc.

questions.question: My husband is six years ……………………….. than me.
questions.description: The adjectives elder and eldest can only be used before a noun. After a verb we use other words like older and oldest. Here we use ‘elder’ because we need a comparative form before ‘than’.

questions.question: I don’t remember him ………………………
questions.description: Well is an adverb good is an adjective. We need an adverb to modify a verb.

questions.question: I could read only the ...................................... chapters of the book.
questions.description: The adjectives first, second, next and last usually go before one, two, three etc.

questions.question: He has few reasons for staying, ..................................?
questions.description: Clauses with little and few are followed by affirmative question tags.

questions.question: He was Catholic, …………………….. most of his friends.
questions.description: As is sometimes followed by auxiliary verb + subject.

questions.question: In 1939, …………………………. in 1914, everybody wanted war.
questions.description: As is a conjunction. It can be used before an expression beginning with a preposition.

questions.question: I never enjoyed ……………………………
questions.description: When life refers to a particular way of living, it is usually uncountable.

questions.question: They kept watch all night, ………………………. robbers should come.
questions.description: Lest is similar to in case.

questions.question: There are ……………………… if you are hungry.
questions.description: Left goes at the end of the structure.

questions.question: ……………………………. cook their own food these days.
questions.description: Before nouns without determiners (articles, possessives etc.), we use fewer without of.

questions.question: I would like to spend ……………………….. my time doing laundry.
questions.description: We use less of before a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: …………………………. have been quite stressful.
questions.description: We generally use ‘the last few days’, not ‘last few days’.

questions.question: Do you enjoy your ………………………….. job?
questions.description: We use latest to refer to very recent things.

questions.question: This is the last letter he …………………………. from me.
questions.description: Both present and future tenses are possible after ‘this is the last ….’

questions.question: Do you know …………………………?
questions.description: Know cannot be followed directly by an infinitive. We use ‘know how to’.

questions.question: I am tired. It is time we …………………….. home
questions.description: After ‘it is time’ we use a past tense with a present meaning.

questions.question: The boy ..................................... for stealing.
questions.description: The boy did not punish he was punished (by somebody else). With the other options, an object would be required to make the sentence complete.

questions.question: I ............................... him for several years.
questions.description: We normally use perfect tenses with the time expressions since and for.

questions.question: ...................................... he continue to be unpunctual, he shall be dismissed.
questions.description: 'Should he continue' here means 'if he continues'.

questions.question: Had he told me earlier, I ...................................... arranged it.
questions.description: The given sentence is in the third conditional. Here we use would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: If that man had drank less, he .................................... developed heart trouble.
questions.description: The given sentence is in the third conditional. Here we use would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: The minister .......................................... the foundation stone of the school.
questions.description: Lied is simple past tense and past participle of lie. Laid is the second form of lay (to keep).

questions.question: All the expenses .................................... by the company.
questions.description: 'By' indicates passive voice. 'Was/were + third form of the verb' is used in the passive voice of simple past tense. 'Expenses' is plural and hence we use 'were' here.

questions.question: Whenever he is in Mumbai, my father ..................................... with us.
questions.description: 'Whenever' indicates a routine. We use the present simple to talk about habits and routines.

questions.question: When I visited him, he ...................................... bedridden for two months.
questions.description: The past perfect continuous is used to talk about an action that started in the past and continued up to later moment in the past.

questions.question: I will call you when dinner ......................................... ready.
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the future tense, we use a present tense in the subordinate clause to indicate future.

questions.question: The war ........................................ for two years, when John enlisted.
questions.description: The past perfect continuous is used to talk about an action that started in the past and continued up to later moment in the past.

questions.question: ............................................ the message, the man departed.
questions.description: The man departed after he had given the message. This is best expressed by the use of the phrase 'having given'.

questions.question: Please don’t use your nail …………. a screwdriver.
questions.description: We use ‘as’ to say what function a person or object has.

questions.question: I don’t like people …………… me in the middle of the night.
questions.description: Like can be followed by an ing form or a to-infinitive.

questions.question: I will let you …………….. my holiday dates next week.
questions.description: Let is followed by an infinitive without to.

questions.question: They kept watch all night lest the robbers ……………. come.
questions.description: Should is the only auxiliary that can be used after lest.

questions.question: I am going to ………….. down for a few minutes.
questions.description: To lie is to be horizontal.

questions.question: I earn ………………. in my family.
questions.description: The least is the superlative of little. It is used before uncountable nouns.

questions.question: Those who know the answer should ………….. their hands.
questions.description: We use raise with an object.

questions.question: She ……………. from her seat.
questions.description: To rise from your seat is to get up.

questions.question: I am very sure ……………… the test.
questions.description: We use sure + infinitive  to talk about our own feelings.

questions.question: She seemed quite sure …………. the exam.
questions.description: Sure + of + ing is used to refer to the feelings of the person you are talking about.

questions.question: I am sorry ……………. my temper yesterday.
questions.description: Sorry + about/for + ing is used to talk about past things we regret.

questions.question: I am sorry …………… you that you failed the test.
questions.description: Sorry + infinitive is used to apologize for current situations.

questions.question: I .......................... to go many days ago.
questions.description: We use the simple past tense with past time expressions like ago.

questions.question: Only ............................... people attended the meeting.
questions.description: We use 'a few' to mean 'some'. Few means almost none.

questions.question: I was late but ........................... were on time.
questions.description: Either 'others' or 'other people' is possible here.

questions.question: I asked his opinion ............................... not to offend him.
Maria, ......................... is on holiday at the moment, is my neighbor.
questions.description: We cannot use 'that' in non-identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: I worked ........................... long.
questions.description: We do not use articles in the expression 'all day'.

questions.question: They ................................ the station before I arrived.
questions.description: We do not use prepositions after reach.

questions.question: I had an enjoyable day ........................ I was one of the winners.
questions.description: Because is a conjunction. Because of is a preposition.

questions.question: ........................... children like chocolates.
questions.description: No article is used before most when we generalize things.

questions.question: I visited them ...........................
questions.description: No article or preposition are used before expressions like next week, last month, next day etc.

questions.question: I don't know ......................... I will be able to come.
questions.description: We can use if or whether to introduce indirect questions.

questions.question: It is time she .................................. to bed.
questions.description: We use past tenses after 'it's time' with present or future reference.

questions.question: She is taller ……………….. her husband.
questions.description: Then is  a time expression than is used in comparative structures.

questions.question: He put the books ………………….. the table.
questions.description: We use in to show position inside three dimensional spaces. On is used to show position on the surface of something.

questions.question: Get the cat ……………….. the piano.
The baby ………………….. his mother.
questions.description: Resemble is one of those verbs that do not take a preposition before its object.

questions.question: The child sat ………………….. his mother.
questions.description: Beside means near or next to. Besides means in addition to.

questions.question: The clown ....................... the audience with his tricks.
questions.description: Amusing is a present participle form. It becomes a verb only when it is used with forms of be.

questions.question: He is nursing a …………………. heart.
It is raining cats and ………………..
I gave ……………….. chemistry because I didn’t like it.
questions.description: To give up is to stop making an effort and accept that you have failed.

questions.question: I can’t wait ……………….. the holidays.
I don't know where ......................... gone.
questions.description: In indirect questions, the subject goes before the verb.

questions.question: He is taller than ......................
questions.description: If there is no verb, object pronouns are more common after than.

questions.question: ………………….. quick results when you start learning a language.
questions.description: Negative imperatives are made with do not + infinitive without to.

questions.question: You seldom work on Saturdays, ………………….?
questions.description: Clauses with words like seldom, hardly, little, and few have a negative sense. Affirmative question tags are used after them.

questions.question: There is little point in doing anything about it, ……………..?
questions.description: Clauses with words like seldom, hardly, little, and few have a negative sense. Affirmative question tags are used after them.

questions.question: He has few reasons for staying, ……………….?
questions.description: Clauses with words like seldom, hardly, little, and few have a negative sense. Affirmative question tags are used after them.

questions.question: I ...................... the flowers. Just after I finished it started raining.
questions.description: We use the structure ‘needn’t have’ to mean that something was unnecessary.

questions.question: She is …………………. a great dancer than I am.
questions.description: We use ‘no more’ with nouns to talk about quantity or degree.

questions.question: .....................… wished me a happy birthday.
questions.description: No one cannot be followed by of. The other two options are possible here.

questions.question: Mother suggested ………………….. a dentist.
questions.description: Suggest cannot be followed by object + infinitive.

questions.question: I didn’t ask …………….. for the meal.
questions.description: Some verbs are followed by object + infinitive.

questions.question: After putting it off many times, we ………………. managed to have a holiday in France.
questions.description: Finally suggests that we have been waiting a long time for something.

questions.question: We made many different plans for our holiday, but …………………. we went to Malaysia again.
questions.description: We use in the end to suggest that something happens after a lot of problems or uncertainty.

questions.question: A declarative sentence has a full stop …………………
questions.description: At the end means position at the end of something.

questions.question: I …………………. to quit my job a few days ago.
questions.description: We cannot use the present perfect tense with time expressions referring to the past.

questions.question: The ……………….. were on time.
questions.description: Others mean the same as other people.

questions.question: I did it ………………….. to offend him.
questions.description: The correct expression is ‘so as to’. In negative expressions we use ‘so as not to’.

questions.question: Jane, …………… is on holiday at the moment, is my colleague.
questions.description: In non-identifying relative clauses, we cannot use that.

questions.question: He works …………………. day long.
questions.description: The correct expression is ‘all day’.

questions.question: We ……………….. the station at 3 o’clock.
questions.description: When reach means 'arrive at', it does not require a preposition before the object.

questions.question: As someone born in the eighties, I like that kind of ………………
questions.description: Music is uncountable. We cannot use the article ‘a’ with uncountable nouns.

questions.question: I had a great day at the races ………………. I won.
questions.description: Because is a conjunction. We use it before a clause. Because of is a preposition. We use it before a noun. Due to is also a preposition.

questions.question: …………….. children like chocolates.
I visited them …………………
questions.description: We do not normally use prepositions before common expressions like yesterday, last week, last year etc.

questions.question: I did it because he ……………… me to do it.
questions.description: 'Ask for' means ask somebody to give something

questions.question: I don’t know …………….. she will come or not.
questions.description: Whether is preferred in a two-part question with or.

questions.question: She is ………………… the best player in the team.
I will be in Mumbai between Monday ………………….. Friday.
questions.description: Note the expressions 'between ...and', 'from...to'

questions.question: He has ……………….. to the market but he should be here soon.
questions.description: Use 'been' for completed visits.

questions.question: The milkman has already …………………..
questions.description: Use 'been' for completed visits.

questions.question: Each …………………. is different.
questions.description: After each and every, you need a singular noun.

questions.question: It gets really hot ……………….. summer.
questions.description: We use 'in' before months and seasons.

questions.question: He was born ………………… a Friday.
questions.description: Before days, we use 'in'.

questions.question: She is regarded ………………….. one of the best dancers ever.
Considered …………………. a whole, the program was quite a success.
She watched the ………………… program.
I watched ………………… the programs.
questions.description: Note the patterns: all + the + noun the + whole + noun
